title: Clean up the Create Project UI experiment
description:
## Summary 

In [conclusion of the experiment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220871#note_422186640), we have decided to proceed with the new [UI for Project Creation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/210599). We need to clean up the experiment, remove the old code and make the new solution permanent.

## Todo

* [x] Conclude [the experiment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220871)
* [x] Remove the `new_create_project_ui` flag
* [x] Remove obsolete code (old views)
* [ ] Update the docs per [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220871#note_362533406)
* [x] Remove `DOMContentLoaded` from `app/assets/javascripts/pages/projects/new/index.js`
* [ ] Clean up the use of `data-qa-selector` in `spec/features/*`
* [x] Organize code to be in permanent location (currently in an "experiment" folder)
* [x] Move SVGs to gitlab-svg repo
* [x] Change `min-width: 215px` to `width: 215px` to ensure SVGs don't get giant
* [x] Add bottom margin on .md sized screens

title: Set DAST_SPIDER_START_AT_HOST default to false
description:
# Context

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/258805 introduced the `DAST_SPIDER_START_AT_HOST` variable, allowing the user to decide if they want the DAST scan to start at the target or the target's host.

The default was set to true to preserve the existing functionality. In %"14.0", we want to switch it to false.

# Solution

Use `config.dast_major_version` to switch the `DAST_SPIDER_START_AT_HOST` to default to `False` when `config.dast_major_version >= 2`

title: Include the Group and Project scope in the empty state message for Global Search
description:
We currently show the group and project scope within the results information when there are results for the search query. However, when there are no results, we do not show this scope within the no results message. It would be helpful to retain this information to reiterate to users that they are searching within a specific group/project.

Additional discussion here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/249265#note_420693734

title: ci_default_git_depth allowed in create but will cause a 500 error
description:
`ci_default_git_depth` is listed in our API docs for `edit`: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/projects.html#create-project

However the way the API is implemented: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/api/helpers/projects_helpers.rb#L60 this parameter is allowed for `create` and will cause a 500 error.

```
± curl --request POST \
  --url http://192.168.1.118:3000/api/v4/projects \
  --header 'accept: application/json' \
  --header 'content-type: application/json' \
  --header 'private-token: OMIT' \
  --data '{"name": "foo",
  "ci_default_git_depth": 5
}'; echo

{"message":"500 Internal Server Error"}
```

This parameter should not be allowed in `create` calls.

title: Make file name link to file in unit test report
description:
### Problem to solve

In #119032, we added a new column to the [unit test report](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/unit_test_reports.html#viewing-unit-test-reports-on-gitlab) to display the name of the spec file that generated each test case in the report along with a copy button to copy the full file path (third column in screenshot below).

![Screen_Shot_2020-10-13_at_11.36.03](/uploads/1000a64a5793a8dc6330511fc11a3a27/Screen_Shot_2020-10-13_at_11.36.03.png)

We would like to **make the file path** shown in the table **into a link that goes to the file** in the project on GitLab.

### Intended users

Anyone involved in reviewing test reports, but especially:

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

### Proposal

Link-ify the path to the file so that clicking on it takes you to the file in the project on GitLab.

**Note:** We have similar links in the code quality report, so we can take inspiration from that to implement them here: we can pass `blob_path` in like we do in the [code quality report (haml)](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/views/projects/pipelines/_tabs_content.html.haml#L35) by adding it to the [tests tab (haml)](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/views/projects/pipelines/_with_tabs.html.haml#L86) and using it as the base of the link.

title: Project Access Tokens - Delete project bot after it's removed from project membership
description:
----
Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220388

Follow-up from "Remove project bot user membership when project access token expires"

In MR !43605, project bot user membership is removed when the project access token expires. We also want to fully delete the user to avoid pressurizing the Users table:

- [ ] @shinya.maeda started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/43605#note_426072666):

    > Removing the project membership doesn't cleanup a bot user itself. This design lets malicious users create many bot accounts (formatted by `project_{project_id}_bot`), which could be a threat model to pressurize the capacity of `users` table.

Checking that the member is a bot, then converting them to a ghost, then destroying the user within `RemoveExpiredMembersWorker` is unperformant:

- [ ] @shinya.maeda started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/43605#note_428808393)

    > This [checking if member is bot then converting to ghost then destroying the user] causes N+1 problem that `SELECT * FROM users WHERE ...` query is executed for each expired member. If this is a desired process, at least we need to execute the process in [batch-style](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/merge_request_performance_guidelines.html#batch-process).

    > This doubles up [the N+1 problem](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/query_recorder.html). Can we avoid this query by reusing the selected user above?

    > This also causes N+1 for `DELETE FROM users ...`. Can we use batch style like mentioned above?

    > I'm not sure if this is a service supposed to be called. Can a domain expert from ~"group::access" can weigh in for double check?

Reverted that last change (destroying the project bot unperformantly) in favor of iterating on that with the guidance of a domain expert.

title: Add check if user is bot to Users API
description:
### Problem to solve 

This is a follow-up from [this discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44085#note_428796085)

With the recent introduction of `Security bot` we added changes to Users popup to show some specific information about bots. Now the check if User is a bot is performed on the frontend, but this is ~"technical debt" and it has to be changed.

 We need to expose info if the user is a bot (Boolean). That change will help to show specific info about bots and increase the credibility of bots.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### User experience goal

Make GitLab bots more credible.

### Proposal

We need to add change to [GET /users/:id](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/users.html#single-user) to expose info if the user is a bot (Boolean).

#### Implementation plan
- [ ] In `lib/api/users.rb` Update 'Get the currently authenticated user' endpoint
  - [ ] Update `Entities::UserPublic` by adding exposing of `bot` field. `expose :bot?, as: :bot do |user| user.bot?
- [ ] Update tests for `lib/api/users.rb`

### Permissions and Security

No change in permissions. 

### Documentation

We need to add a new field to [the api doc](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/users.html#single-user)

### Availability & Testing

need to add relevant tests for the api endpoint and serializers.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

TBA

### What is the type of buyer?

Same as buyer of auto-fix feature.

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

Yes, ~"group::composition analysis" is working on Security bot, but in general bots belong to ~"group::access" 

### Links / references

[discussion about the need of this change](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44085#note_428796085)

description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work
<!--
A brief explanation of the why, not the what or how. Assume the reader doesn't know the
background and won't have time to dig-up information from comment threads.
-->
Currently for a MR, after the pipeline for the MR completes, a security report summary is shown on the MR page:

||

|![ksnip_20201012-215337](/uploads/0c48ed613b4a157e45ddcdbdcfd02a27/ksnip_20201012-215337.png)|

We want to improve the summary message by simplifying the wording and using colors to surface the most important information.

title: The merge train button should not be enabled if there are MR dependencies
description:
The merge train button should be disabled if there are MR dependencies

![image](/uploads/6b42f757b4d30e6bcdcc2a7a91026830/image.png)

Clicking the button results in this message, which is very confusing:

![Screen_Shot_2020-10-13_at_2.01.34_PM](/uploads/70f90c07830dd9a3aeffe5476d7da468/Screen_Shot_2020-10-13_at_2.01.34_PM.png)

Furthermore, we improved the “merge blocked” message in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/82206 but that is not reflected here. It should read: `Merge blocked: all merge request dependencies must be merged.`

title: Remove Banzai::Renderer::CommonMark::HTML
description:
## Summary This issue was created from this discussion https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/263114#note_428271807. We currently implement a custom [`commonmarker`](https://github.com/gjtorikian/commonmarker) rendering class [`Banzai::Renderer::CommonMark::HTML`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/8d52eeccf8d069b0cbb43be66311489544373c2d/lib/banzai/renderer/common_mark/html.rb) which has the sole purpose of producing fenced code blocks in a format that renders nicely on GitLab.com (see [this code comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/8afa2a10ec5512f95777e383ccf3f68e4959f605/lib/banzai/filter/markdown_engines/common_mark.rb#L26-30)). ## Problem @toupeira noticed https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/263114#note_428271807 an issue https://github.com/gjtorikian/commonmarker/issues/112 that mentioned that doing so makes a renderer that is an ["all or nothing"](https://github.com/gjtorikian/commonmarker/issues/112#issuecomment-570902032) override of the C class with Ruby. From https://github.com/gjtorikian/commonmarker/issues/112#issue-545161219, the style of rendering benchmarked as 10x slower (`commonmarker_our_custom_renderer`) is how we [currently render markdown](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/8afa2a10ec5512f95777e383ccf3f68e4959f605/lib/banzai/filter/markdown_engines/common_mark.rb#L46-50). #### Example code block styles Our `Banzai::Filter::MarkdownEngines::CommonMark` class currently outputs code blocks like this: ```html 
some code\n
``` GitHub-style looks like this: ```html 
some code\n
``` And default Markdown style looks like this: ```html 
puts 1\n
``` ## Improvements If we can delete [`Banzai::Renderer::CommonMark::HTML`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/8d52eeccf8d069b0cbb43be66311489544373c2d/lib/banzai/renderer/common_mark/html.rb) we might get ~10x speed up improvement in rendering markdown. We could either: 1. Move the customising of the fenced code block that [`Banzai::Renderer::CommonMark::HTML`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/8d52eeccf8d069b0cbb43be66311489544373c2d/lib/banzai/renderer/common_mark/html.rb) produces into another part of the Banzai pipeline. 1. Modify however GitLab renders fenced code blocks so that it works with either [GitHub-style code fences](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/8afa2a10ec5512f95777e383ccf3f68e4959f605/lib/banzai/filter/markdown_engines/common_mark.rb#L26-30) or CommonMarker's default rendering of fenced code blocks. ## Risks We want to make sure that cached markup continues to work. ## Involved components TBD.

title: SAML Group Sync - Add/Remove Groups
description:
<!-- The first section "Release notes" is required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated. Currently in BETA, details on the **release post item generator** can be found in the handbook:  https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#release-post-item-generator and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg. The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. 

### Release notes

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve

Once SAML groups have been mapped, we should check the groups section in a SAML assertion. If the SAML group is found then we should add the user to that GitLab group. If the SAML group isn't found then we should remove the user from that GitLab group. 

### Intended users


* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)


### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses?
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ -->


### Proposal

* Sync process on user sign-in
  1. User signs in via Group SAML
  1. Sign-in kicks off a `SamlGroupSync` worker from `Gitlab::Auth::GroupSaml::User#find_and_update!`. Parameters likely need to consist of at least:
     * User ID
     * Top-level group ID
     * Array of Group Names from IdP
  1. Worker will query for group links where:
     * `group_id` is in the list of IDs contained within the top-level group. This can be obtained via `Group#self_and_descendents`.
     * `group_name` is in the array of group names from the IdP
  1. Worker adds the user as a member of the groups at the respective access level.

**NOTE:** The last MR (if there are multiple MRs in this issue) should default enable the `:saml_group_links` feature flag introduced in !45080. We can keep the feature flag around for a while in case we need to disable the feature for any reason. 

During implementation we should consider how to make the worker and/or service classes reusable for other sync-on-sign-in solutions, such as for OAuth.

Everything built here can also be used for instance-level sync. The only difference needed, as an example, is to pass a `nil` value for top-level group ID for the worker. In this case the worker can query for *any* group in the whole instance by name and add members accordingly. And instead of the worker being kicked off from `Gitlab::Auth::GroupSaml::User` it is called from `Gitlab::Auth::Saml::User`. We should keep this in mind during implementation, especially during the worker creation phase so the parameters and usage feels natural for either case.

The supported way to pass groups via SAML will be the same as is currently supported for self-managed admin and external groups: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/integration/saml.html#requirements

```xml
    <saml2:AttributeStatement>
      <saml2:Attribute Name="Groups" NameFormat="urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:attrname-format:basic">
        <saml2:AttributeValue xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:type="xs:string">Everyone</saml2:AttributeValue>
        <saml2:AttributeValue xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:type="xs:string">DBlessing Test Group</saml2:AttributeValue>
      </saml2:Attribute>
    </saml2:AttributeStatement>
```

In the initial implementation we should only support attribute statements with the name 'Groups'. Later we can make this configurable like it is for self-managed. For self-managed, the 'Groups' are obtained from the auth_hash (see [`Gitlab::Auth::Saml::AuthHash`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6708856194b9aa1d7441d7da87ec7722e13bace7/lib/gitlab/auth/saml/auth_hash.rb#L7)).

### Further details

This is an Ultimate level feature.

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?
Consider adding checkboxes and expectations of users with certain levels of membership https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html
* [ ] Add expected impact to members with no access (0)
* [ ] Add expected impact to Guest (10) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Reporter (20) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Developer (30) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Maintainer (40) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Owner (50) members -->

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/workflow.html#for-a-product-change

* If this feature requires changing permissions, update the permissions document. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html -->

### Availability & Testing

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

A new end-to-end test would be need to cover this feature. Testcase issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/quality/testcases/-/issues/1072

title: SAML Group Sync -  Setup UI in Groups
description:
<!-- The first section "Release notes" is required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated. Currently in BETA, details on the **release post item generator** can be found in the handbook:  https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#release-post-item-generator and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg. The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. 

### Release notes

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve

As part of SAML group sync, we need to have a place within groups to set up group mapping. The setup experience will be similar to [LDAP group mapping](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/index.html#manage-group-memberships-via-ldap). 

### Intended users

* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
-->

### User experience goal

Users are able to map groups from their idp to gitlab groups.

### Proposal

Create a new table `saml_group_links` where `group_name` corresponds to the SAML IdP provided group names and `group_id` corresponds to the GitLab group this link belongs to.

  ```sql
  CREATE TABLE saml_group_links (
    id integer NOT NULL,
    group_name character varying NOT NULL,
    access_level integer NOT NULL,
    group_id integer NOT NULL,
    created_at timestamp without time zone,
    updated_at timestamp without time zone
  );
  ```
* Each GitLab group can have multiple group links at a specific access level. If a user matches multiple group links for the same GitLab group we use the max access level.
* Create a new 'SAML Group Links' submenu under 'Settings'. This new menu item and page will be accessible on *all* subgroups when SAML SSO is enabled. UI will be similar to [LDAP Group Links](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/index.html#creating-group-links-via-cn) and will consist of a form with the following fields and a list of all existing group links:
  * Group Name: Corresponds to group names that will be sent from SAML IdP
  * Access Level: 'Developer', 'Maintainer', etc

The end goal of the attached epic is that the group name from the `SamlGroupLink` will be matched with the group name passed by the IdP as in the example below. Users will then be assigned the `access_level` specified in the `SamlGroupLink`.

The supported way to pass groups via SAML will be the same as is currently supported for self-managed admin and external groups: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/integration/saml.html#requirements

```xml
    <saml2:AttributeStatement>
      <saml2:Attribute Name="Groups" NameFormat="urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:attrname-format:basic">
        <saml2:AttributeValue xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:type="xs:string">Everyone</saml2:AttributeValue>
        <saml2:AttributeValue xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:type="xs:string">DBlessing Test Group</saml2:AttributeValue>
      </saml2:Attribute>
    </saml2:AttributeStatement>
```

In this initial implementation, we only support attribute statements with the name 'Groups'.  This can be configurable in the future.

### Further details

This is an Ultimate level feature.

### Permissions and Security

title: New group empty state
description:
### Problem to solve

During [CMS testing for subgroups](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-design/-/issues/1331) users had a hard time finding how to create a new subgroup.  Even though we have an empty state no users read the text for guidance on what to do next.

![Screen_Shot_2020-10-13_at_1.00.09_PM](/uploads/21cb80ea4ccfb4d977bbb22552634002/Screen_Shot_2020-10-13_at_1.00.09_PM.png)

### Intended users

Anyone who creates a group!

### User experience goal

Creating a subgroups is discoverable.


## Proposal

#### 🎨 [Figma work file](https://www.figma.com/file/QR0uCu8XWeRdQac1YpaVrq/267113-Seperate-group-and-project-creation?node-id=112%3A3127)
- Remove feature flags and overlapping tests
- create two cards for new sub group ([svg](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-svgs/illustrations/?q=illustrations%2Fgroup-new.svg)) and new project ([svg](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-svgs/illustrations/?q=illustrations%2Fproject-create-new-sm.svg))
- attach tracking metrics to the two cards, and the two buttons `New subgroup` and `New project`

![Group-empty_state](/uploads/0dee94474e42af900a52d50c92c2360d/Group-empty_state.png)

## Availability and Testing

- Ensure sufficient coverage in unit, integration and component tests
- Update and add new scenarios to feature specs. Some specs that would be good to review:
    - `spec/features/groups/empty_states_spec.rb`
    - `spec/features/groups_spec.rb`
    - `spec/features/groups/show_spec.rb`

title: [VSA] Add an allowable production environment name of "prod"
description:
### Problem to solve

Currently Value Stream Analytics expects the production environment to be called `production`.  A customer has requested that the common abbreviation `prod` also be accepted.

### Proposal

Value Stream Analytics should allow `prod` to be considered an expected name for the production environment (in addition to `production`).

### Related links

- The [original Slack message from the customer](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CTENFHN8H/p1602107894024200) said: "Is there any way to customize this? Our production environment is called `prod`."

title: Group packages API is slow for large groups
description:
The `/api/v4/groups/:name/packages` endpoint is slow for very large groups.

The slow method is:

```ruby
    def group_projects_visible_to_current_user
      ::Project
        .in_namespace(groups)
        .public_or_visible_to_user(current_user, Gitlab::Access::REPORTER)
        .with_project_feature
        .select { |project| Ability.allowed?(current_user, :read_package, project) }
    end
```

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/147ad05bb19727443393762b585ada27c31a3b15/app/finders/packages/group_packages_finder.rb#L38-44

In this example, `Ability.allowed?` was called ~11k times.

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2815 has more details including a profile of a request to the URL.

title: [VSA] New value stream not loaded after creating it
description:
### Problem to solve

It is possible to create custom value streams in group-level Value Stream Analytics.  However, after creating one, the user is not redirected to that value stream.  The user remains on the value stream that was loaded when clicking to create a new one.

### Proposal

After creating a new group-level value stream, the user should be redirected to the newly-created value stream.

### Screenshots

![Screen_Shot_2020-10-12_at_12.32.16_PM](/uploads/f0b57aa52c83fc1bf06200b12091bc61/Screen_Shot_2020-10-12_at_12.32.16_PM.png)

title: [MR Analytics] Filtering for label is broken
description:
### Problem to solve

In [Merge Request Analytics for gitlab-org/gitlab](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/analytics/merge_request_analytics), one label is autosuggested by default (see 1st screenshot below), and none are autosuggested by search.  It seems the backend is returning empty result sets (see 2nd screenshot below).

### Expected behavior

In Merge Request Analytics, the `label` filter should return all available options for autosuggest.

### Screenshot

For some reason there is one autosuggest option:

![Screen_Shot_2020-10-12_at_12.11.40_PM](/uploads/11ef7f572f4dac546a9862fcde647c8e/Screen_Shot_2020-10-12_at_12.11.40_PM.png)

However, there are no options returned in search:

![Screen_Shot_2020-10-12_at_12.15.56_PM](/uploads/41193fe42addb4384d946da8605d1839/Screen_Shot_2020-10-12_at_12.15.56_PM.png)

title: Temporary project maintainer can gain permanent access by re-inviting themselves to the project without an expiration date
description:
### Summary A project maintainer whose access been granted with an expiration date may override the expiration by going to `Project -> Members` and inviting themselves to the project again. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Add a user to a project with Maintainer access and an expiration date 1. Sign in / impersonate this user 1. Go to the `Project -> Members` page 1. Search for the temporary maintainer and grant Maintainer access again, but with no expiration date 1. The user now has permanent access to the project ### Example Project ### What is the current *bug* behavior? Maintainers with temporary access can grant themselves permanent access. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? title: Application setting "size limit per repository" is 9.8GB, but we state 10GB is the limit
description:
We've got a mix of [MiB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mebibyte) and [MB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megabyte) annotations in our codebase.

> Despite its official status, the unit mebibyte is not commonly used even when reporting byte counts calculated in binary multiples, but is often represented as a megabyte. The discrepancy may cause confusion, since operating systems using the binary method report lower numerical values for storage size than advertised by manufacturers, such as disk drive manufacturers, who strictly use decimal units. 

:point_up: This confusion can be seen in the settings for GitLab.com as we [state a 10GB](https://about.gitlab.com/blog/2015/04/08/gitlab-dot-com-storage-limit-raised-to-10gb-per-repo/), set it at `10.000MB`, but then we display the limit on the 1024^2 scale (`9.8GiB`)
 
| Setting | in-app usage |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![Screen_Shot_2020-10-12_at_9.17.39](/uploads/74987c24cbf8d016fe0d37bc15d9e901/Screen_Shot_2020-10-12_at_9.17.39.png) | ![](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/2be62bf9e83295d89f18ea43a72d16b5/Screenshot_2020-10-12_at_18.05.11.png) |


### Suggested solution

1. Set `Size limit per repository` to 10240 so we get 10GB showing to the user.

title: Build deck for UX Showcase
Backend/Quality: Create system tests for manually running new pipelines with custom variables
description:
### Problem to solve

In a recent incident, manually run pipelines were not setting the custom variables correctly. This was a regression caused by a change in the code base but it was not caught by any system tests and subsequently made it to production.

This change was introduced behind a feature flag so it may be that the tests are there, they are just testing with that flag turned off and won't catch the regression.

### Proposal

We need a system test that triggers a manual pipeline with custom variables and checks the output to make sure they're being passed through correctly.

If this test alrerady exists, it needs to be modified so it checks the outcome with the feature flag toggled both off and on.

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/verify-stage/-/issues/35

title: Improve audit event preloading logic for CSV export
description:
## Problems

As pointed out by @ahegyi, the current audit event preloading logic is not optimal. Especially for export to CSV use case, the preloading logic tries to preload all associated user record on 100k of audit event. This cause heavy strain on memory and significant slow down the whole export process.

## Proposal

1. The preloader still forces the whole scope to be loaded (no LIMIT). See a potential fix in this branch: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/compare/master...audit-event-export-improvement-adam-hegyi
1. The `find_each` forces ordering by `id` which is not covered by an index. We need an index on `created_at, id` fields.

title: Follow-up from "Add support for manual bridges for CI pipelines"
description:

- [x] @fabiopitino started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44011#note_428062377):

    >

- [x] @fabiopitino started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44011#note_428062378): 

    > Could this be moved to `Entry::Processable`?

- [ ] @fabiopitino started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44011#note_428062418): 

    > Could we move `action?` to `Processable` and have here a temporary override according to the feature flag state?
    > 
    > ```ruby
    > class Ci::Processable
    >   def action?
    >     # we would control in the entry validation whether `delayed`
    >     # is allowed or not.
    >     %w[manual delayed].include?(self.when)
    >   end
    > end
    > 
    > class Ci::Bridge
    >   override :action?
    >   def action?
    >     return false unless ::Gitlab::Ci::Features.manual_bridges_enabled?(project)
    >   
    >     super
    >   end
    > end
    > ```


- [ ] @fabiopitino started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44011#note_428062442): 

    > Should this and relative spec from `Ci::Build` be moved to `Ci::Processable` to remove duplication?

/cc @furkanayhan

title: Remove duplication between PlayBridgeService and PlayBuildService
description:
The following discussion from !44011 should be addressed:

- [ ] @fabiopitino started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44011#note_428062465):  (+1 comment)

    > There is something I'm not quite convinced about this design because we are taking in input `job_variables_attributes` but not using them here. I feel at least we should add a comment about it.
    > 
    > There is also some duplication between `PlayBridgeService` and `PlayBuildService` and I'm wondering how we could remove that. It seems that `PlayBuildService` performs a retry if the enqueue is not possible, while the `PlayBridgeService` only needs the enqueue. :thinking: 
    > 
    > Maybe something like this makes sense?
    > 
    > ```ruby
    > class Ci::Bridge
    >   def play(current_user, _job_variables_attributes = {})
    >     Ci::PlayJobService.new(project, current_user).execute(self)
    >   end
    > end
    > 
    > class Ci::Build
    >   def play(current_user, job_variables_attributes = nil)
    >     
    >     Ci::PlayJobService.new(project, current_user).execute(self, job_variables_attributes) || 
    >       Ci::Build.retry(self, current_user)
    >   end
    > end
    > 
    > class Ci::PlayJobService < ::BaseService
    >   def execute(job, job_variables_attributes = nil)
    >     job.tap |playable|
    >       playable.user = current_user
    >       playable.job_variables_attributes = job_variables_attributes || []
    >       playable.enqueue!
    >     end
    > 
    >   rescue StateMachines::InvalidTransition
    >     # no-op
    >   end
    > end
    > ```

- [ ] @fabiopitino started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44011#note_428062463):  (+2 comments)

    > There is some difference in behavior with `PlayBuildService` where we don't raise exceptions aside from the `AccessDeniedError`. Here we seem we could raise a state machine error. 
    > 
    > Would this result in a 500 page?

    > we should convert these services to return a `ServiceResponse` object, either `success` or `error`. This way we can handle failures gracefully.

/cc @furkanayhan

title: Merge YAML block from includes
description:
This issue is a followup from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/16376#note_423199984


### Release notes

Previously it was impossible to refer to sections of a yaml file to be used as a part of your pipeline, in this release we've allowed you to merge specific keys from multiple yaml file into a single pipeline configuration, this allows you to maintain a single location of pipeline actions (such as setups, teardowns, etc...) to be used and referred along side your jobs.


### Problem to solve

We would like to merge content from another YAML file to support the following:

```yaml
# Content of setup.yml
.setup:
  script:
    - echo creating environment1 
    - echo creating environment2

# Content of teardown.yml
.teardown:
  script:
    - echo deleting environment1
    - echo deleting environment2

# .gitlab-ci.yml
include:
    local: setup.yml
    local: teardown.yml
 
test:
  script:
    - !reference [.setup, script] # or any other name that would allow us to "include in this context some other value"
    - echo running my own command
    - !reference [.teardown, script]
```

This will result in the following:

```
echo creating environment1 
echo creating environment2
echo running my own command
echo deleting environment1
echo deleting environment2
```
The example below will merge script however we need to make sure to support any other key that is under job such as `rules`

The following section in the documentation needs to get updated
https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/README.html#include

title: Incorrect Project badge text-link relationship for JavaScript on gitlab-org/gitlab
description:

title: File search window doesn't get correct focus.
description:
### Edit Feb 3, 2021

by: @jboyson 

I've moved my comment up here for more visibility. Below is what I found researching potential causes for this issue. Given that, myself and others cannot recreate the problem and the very narrow situation that I can see this happening, I am closing this issue.

I suspect that some interruption in javascript processing delayed the file input getting focus. It is possible that some other change unknowingly corrected this problem.

If you run into it again, please open another issue, thanks! :bow: 

I've done some discovery and I can only think of one obscure way for this to happen.

**NOTE: I have not been able to actually reproduce this. This is purely speculation.**

`s` is the keyboard shortcut for focusing on the search bar. It is technically possible to focus the search bar if `s` is pressed after the page loads, but before the file input is focused. Maybe if something had hung up the javascript.

Notice in the example video that it is highly likely that `s` was the first key pressed.

I am not sure how to address this if we can't reproduce the problem. We could do something really heavy-handed like disabling the `s` shortcut on the find file page, but I am **strongly** against this idea.

## Details

- Pressing `t` just loads a URL. The shortcut itself does not set any focus.
- The find path input is focused on page load here: `app/assets/javascripts/project_find_file.js:52`

Only three events focus the search input:

1. Clicking the search input
2. Clicking the clear button (the `x`) after text is entered into the search input
3. Pressing `s` on the keyboard

See `app/assets/javascripts/search_autocomplete.js` lines 410 and 467
and `app/assets/javascripts/behaviors/shortcuts/shortcuts.js:183`

Since both of those are click events it should not be possible for the search bar to auto focus.

### Summary

If you press t to search through the files in the directory tree the focus ends up on the wrong textbox

### Steps to reproduce

Press t, type something, the focus is on the Search or jump to... box

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The focus is on the Search or jump to box

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The focus should be on the Find by path input.
![Screen_Shot_2020-10-10_at_5.38.49_PM](/uploads/2ac520695e0a6d827d79f871ab75e008/Screen_Shot_2020-10-10_at_5.38.49_PM.png)
![Screen_Shot_2020-10-10_at_5.39.09_PM](/uploads/cf1b2397a4532c4940ce2a8267cf8795/Screen_Shot_2020-10-10_at_5.39.09_PM.png)

title: Follow-up from "Resolve problem with rendering thumbsup emoji"
description:
The following discussion from !44818 should be addressed:

- [ ] @alexkalderimis started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44818#note_426815887):  (+3 comments)

    > I think moving the reference filter for vulnerabilities to a different section so it has a different precedence is OK as quick fix but it has the problems that:
    > 
    > - it is unintuitive. A developer might see it as miscategorized, move it, and wonder why things fail
    > - it is now impossible to get a pipeline that has filters but not this reference filter
    > 
    > I think the correct solution is either:
    > 
    > - Negative look around in the reference pattern to detect the emoji colons. This would work for this situation, but is brittle and narrow in scope
    > - we rethink the filter sets in the pipeline by, for example, adding priorities to each one, and sorting them by those when constructing the pipeline
    > - adding comments explaining the conflict
    > - move to adopt a different reference syntax really quite urgently. The markdown already looks like ASCII soup, and discoverability is low. 
    > 
    > Considering how common the `+1` string must be, I'm surprised this hasn't shown up more generally

## Implementation Plan

1. Roll-back/remove the feature

title: Add event timestamp to deployments webhooks
description:

The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Release notes
Visualizations of deployment webhook data now have an event transition timestamp event to anchor chronologically.

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve
Some webhooks (jobs and deployments for example) from gitlab.com webhooks do not contain timestamp information in their json payload. This is usually found in object_attributes -> created_at in other webhooks.

Timestamps are helpful to retain real-time data stream of events for downstream actions. Part of these actions may want to understand when the event actually occurred and the best guess is when the webhook was received. This creates data integrity challenges and doesn't allow the downstream systems to draw visualizations based on actual event times.
<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

description:
A customer encountered an error during a DR failover/failback test when turning a former primary into a secondary and setting up PG streaming replication. title: Can't set "never" as an environment auto_stop_in value
description:
### Summary

The documentation for the CI environment "auto-stop" feature indicates that "`auto_stop_in` uses the same format of `artifacts:expire_in` docs".

However "never" is not a valid option, despite being clearly listed as valid in the `artifacts:expire_in` documentation.

This means that the "obvious" way to create persistent environments - setting `auto_stop_in` to "never" - doesn't work.

(I understand that you're supposed to use protected environments for production environments, but that's less discoverable if you're looking at environments from the CI YAML reference.)

Documentation links:

* CI YAML reference for `environment:auto_stop_in`: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/#environmentauto_stop_in
* Environment reference for the "auto-stop" feature: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/index.html#environments-auto-stop
* CI YAML reference for `artifacts:expire_in`: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/README.html#artifactsexpire_in
* Protected environments: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/protected_environments.html

### Steps to reproduce

Example `.gitlab-ci.yml` file:

```yaml
deploy_persistent:
  script:
    - echo "deploy the thing"

  environment:
    name: persistent-environment
    auto_stop_in: never
```

1. Define a pipeline job with an environment that should be persistent
2. Set `environment:auto_stop_in` to "never"
3. Lint the CI script

### Example Project

I have not created an example project as the issue can be reproduced with the CI Linter in any project.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The current behaviour is that the linting fails with the error:

```
jobs:deploy_persistent:environment auto stop in should be a duration
```

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

According to the documentation, "never" should be a valid duration and therefore the linting should succeed.

I'd expect that an environment created by a job with `auto_stop_in` set to "never" would have no "auto stop in" time set, identically to what would happen if the "pin" button had been pressed.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

[gitlab-ci-environment-auto_stop_in-never-bug](/uploads/53875257eaf9cd6cdc7d58e8641709dd/gitlab-ci-environment-auto_stop_in-never-bug.png)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com.

### Possible fixes

When the "environment:auto_stop_in" key was added it was set to be a "duration" type value: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/19931/diffs#e847be0aa4579071063b7903a5e8b6eafa8228b0_52_52 (Current code: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/config/entry/environment.rb#L52)
However the "artifacts:expire_in" key uses it's own custom parser: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/config/entry/artifacts.rb#L45

I suspect that the correct fix here is for the `environment:auto_stop_in` key to use the same parser and logic as the `artifacts:expire_in` key.

However it's also possible that this particular feature - creating environments without an expiry time - is unwanted and the protected environment feature should be used instead, in which case the correct solution here is to update the documentation to make it explicit that `environment:auto_stop_in` _must_ be a duration and "never" isn't allowed.

### Proposal

Allow a user to define `when: never`as part of `auto-stop` in

title: Investigate: Dogfooding the GitLab npm registry
description:
### Topic to Evaluate

In %11.7, GitLab released the MVC of the npm registry. We've continued to improve the feature and today tens of thousands of node packages are published to and installed from the registry each day, more if you count packages installed using the [npm request forwarding feature](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/npm_registry/#forwarding-requests-to-npmjsorg), which will look in the public registry for any packages not found in your GitLab registry. In addition, you can now authenticate with your personal access, job, deploy (group or project), and project access tokens.

And in %"13.6" we will add a project level endpoint that supports all npm commands, so you won't have to maintain `publishconfig` in each package.json. 

It's not all :sunny: and :rainbow: though. We don't yet support caching external dependencies and when a package is pulled using the request forwarding, we don't pass that data to the front end. But those are things we are working on over the next several months. (check https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3608 for more details)

OK so,  I'd like to reevaluate what has to be true for GitLab.com to dogfood the npm registry. Working with the GitLab team would give the  ~"group::package" feedback on how to improve the product and help our customers with real-world examples. 

### Tasks to  Evaluate
- [ ] How does the GitLab team interact with npm? What are the various workflows that any package registry would need to support?
- [ ] Are there missing features from GitLab Packages that prevent us from dogfooding the npm registry? What are they?  
- [ ] What is the level of effort for adopting the registry? Is there a good first iteration/MVC? 
- [ ] Are there any risks to implementing this? To our customers? 

### Risks and Implementation Considerations 

<!-- Identify any risks found in the research, whether this is performance, impacts to other functionality or other bugs -->

### Links
- https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/npm_registry/

title: [Feature flag] Enable merge_base_pipeline for comparing with merged results in the CodeQuality MR widget
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## What

Remove the `:merge_base_pipelines` feature flag ...

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::testing" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_testing`
- Best individual to reach out to: @drewcimino 

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

We're expecting that an existing pipeline run on the commit of a merged result pipeline's `target_sha` will produce a cleaner artifact diff with the merged result head pipeline than the pipeline from the MR `diff_base`, currently called `base_pipeline`.

We will be fetching exactly one pipeline in place of the current `base_pipeline`, so we don't expect any adverse ~performance effects.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

CodeQuality comparisons may not be available if this doesn't return a pipeline and the widget has no base artifact to diff from. In that case, we turn it off and none of the new code in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44648 will execute.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

We'll be checking [this merge request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/45321) to see if the unrelated violations and fixes stop showing up. While that happens, we'll be keeping an eye on the [MergeRequestsController#show](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/web-rails-controller/web-rails-controller?orgId=1&var-PROMETHEUS_DS=Global&var-action=show&var-controller=Projects::MergeRequestsController&var-environment=gprd&var-stage=main&from=now-15m&to=now) dashboard along with [ArtifactsController#download/download.json](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/web-rails-controller/web-rails-controller?orgId=1&from=now-15m&to=now&var-PROMETHEUS_DS=Global&var-environment=gprd&var-stage=main&var-controller=Projects::ArtifactsController&var-action=download&var-action=download.json)

## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- [x] `drewcimino/test-code-quality-template`
- [x] some `gitlab-org` satellite projects?
- [x] `gitlab-org/gitlab` project from 20-22 UTC on 20 October 2020
- [x] Leave on for `gitlab-org/gitlab`
- [x] `gitlab-org`/`gitlab-com` groups
- [x] `.com` ?

## Roll Out Steps

- [x] Enable on staging (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true --staging`)
- [x] Test on staging
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour  (`/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab feature_name true`)
- [ ] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with `#production` and `#g_delivery` on slack.
- [x] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production` (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true`)
- [x] Cross post ~~flag chatops Slack command to `#support_gitlab-com`~~ ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your :thumbsup: team channel :thumbsup: 
- [x] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [x] Remove feature flag and add changelog entry
- [x] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

title: Notify Data Team Engineers when changes to structure.sql occur
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/43703#note_426391850 we identified that it would be beneficial for the Data Team to be notified when changes to `structure.sql` are made - particular _deletions_ of columns. 

@iroussos proposed a change to either Danger Bot or to the Database Review Guidelines:

1. Update danger to also include / ping the Data Team whenever an MR is labeled as ~"database::review pending"

   That means that the Data Team will get some false positives (e.g. updates on finders), but seems like the easiest first iteration.

   A more proper way to do that would be to add a new rule for danger to notify / include the Data Team when changes in `db/structure.sql` are committed in an MR.

   That will generate way less false positives and no false negatives (all schema changes are reflected in `db/structure.sql`), and the Data Team will always be in the loop early in the process.

1. Update the [Database Review Guidelines](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/database_review.html) to require that the Data Team is pinged once an MR with a schema change is ready to be merged.

   That will generate way less noise for the Data Team, but there is always the risk that both the author of an MR and the reviewers will forget to ping the Data Team.

   Even if danger added a simple notification message, people could miss it.

---

I think on the Data Team side we're willing to try the Danger Bot route, we'd just need some help getting it properly set up.

cc @gitlab-data/engineers

title: Show total projects, average coverage and total coverage jobs for today
description:

### Release notes

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve

As an application development director/manager, I want to navigate to a single page to see the current test coverage of all projects in a group, so I can report that data on demand quickly as needed.

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)

### User experience goal

The user should be able to use the UI within GitLab to see a single value of test coverage for all projects in a group.

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->
#### Backend
- **This feature is for EE.**
- **This feature is behind the ~"feature flag" `group_coverage_data_report_graph`.**
- **This should be for the `default` branch only for each project.**
* Create the GroupCodeCoverage (or a better name) GraphQL entity **for today**
  - Total projects
  - Average coverage
  - Total jobs
* The entity should contain the fields required (total projects, average coverage, total jobs) to represent at least the top three numbers in the design, but we should keep in mind that we are going to move on towards implementing the graph next. So the historical information, if added easily, should also be added. If it is more complex, we can put a pin in it until https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/215140.


#### Frontend
* Add an "Overall Activity" section to the Repositories Analytics page (see attached design)
  * In this section, display three coverage statistics for the group (using GraphQL to get the data):
    * `Projects with Tests`
    * `Average Coverage by Job` (final name TBD)
    * `Total Number of Coverages`
  * Potentially, add a [GlAreaChart](https://design.gitlab.com/data-visualization/charts/code) below these statistics displaying just one data point for today's average coverage (which we will expand out to show the historical coverage trend in #215140)

### Further details

* This iteration of the feature does not include sub-group projects. That will be [done later](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/273527).

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

The permissions for this should follow the same permissions as the rest of the group code coverage feature.

description:
The following discussion from !44718 should be addressed:

When cleaning up the Snippet controllers, neither @fjsanpedro nor I could be sure that the JSON handling in the Snippets#show action wasn't still being used, so rather than putting the multi-file snippet release at risk during 13.5, we've left this in for removal in 13.6 instead.

title: Expose metric to track index rebuilds through prometheus
description:
In order to visualize status and impact of reindexing, we are going to expose prometheus metrics for that.

This can be based on the activity and results tracking, that is already implemented. For example, we capture when we start a reindexing action and we also capture the end and the result of it.

* Allow observing the current state of reindexing (what is currently running?) and the history of events (when did we see reindexing actions?)
* We may want to report impact of reindexing (size reduction of indexes) over time, too.

title: Set user availability [BE]
description:
### Problem to solve

This is the ~backend implementation issue for the feature to [set user availability](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/259649).  Specifically, the backend must be able to support the "busy" checkbox that will be added to the user status modal.

### Proposal

- User should have an "availability" enum attribute.  (While there is currently only 1 availability option of "busy", there are strong plans to add more options like "OOO", so we probably should NOT implement "busy" as a boolean attribute.)
- This attribute should be exposed for the following features:
  - User status modal (accessible from the "edit profile" page)
  - Profile page
  - `user_menu` in the top right of the navbar
  - user details hover at the top of issuables and notes
  - user details hover on username autocomplete (when typing in notes)

### Related links

- This "availability" feature is needed to un-block the [Merge Request reviewer workload dashboard](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/227217).

title: Errors from test report parsing should be surfaced to the UI
description:
### Overview
Since the refactoring of the unit test report page to use the [test_report_summary](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/ci/pipeline.rb#L920-924) mechanism we are no longer surfacing parsing errors to the UI. 

### Problem to solve

As a GitLab user, I want to see detailed error information surfaced to the UI when my unit test reports cannot be parsed for some reason in order to fix those errors and enable myself to use this feature.

### Proposal
We need to display the error in two places:

1. MR Widget, probably include the error in the `test_reports.json` response.
1. Test Summary on the pipelines page.

#### Backend
1. Persist `suite_error` in our [summary data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/services/ci/build_report_result_service.rb#L28-39) - **test_suite.suite_error**
1. Create new method in our [TestSuiteSummary](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/reports/test_suite_summary.rb)
1. Expose it in our [TestSuiteSummaryEntity API](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/serializers/test_suite_summary_entity.rb)
1. Level up the `suite_error` at the [TestReportSummary level](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/reports/test_report_summary.rb)
1. Expose it to our [TestReportSummary entity](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/serializers/test_report_summary_entity.rb)
1. :tada: we are now able to expose errors on the ~frontend

#### Frontend

the ~frontend work consists of conditionally showing an error message on the test suite if that suite's test report is invalid (which I'm assuming the ~backend will be including in the already existing response).

### Original Issue

The following discussion from !44615 should be addressed:

- [ ] @iamricecake started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44615#note_426298180): 

    > This message will be set in `test_suite.set_suite_error("JUnit data parsing failed: #{e}")`. But looks like we don't display the `TestSuite#suite_error` anymore on the UI. The `suite_error` is returned in this [endpoint](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/4f6cdc16b3779b4fcf798badb0e9ca61ad142323/app/controllers/projects/pipelines_controller.rb#L202-206) but it's not used anymore.
    > 
    > We have to fix this in a follow-up to provide a helpful error message to the user.

This would require both ~backend and ~frontend work.

title: 🎨 Inform user about price(pipeline minutes) when we introduce continuous fuzzing
description:
#### Problem 

For .com user who uses our shared runner, they have a quota of running pipeline. [detail](https://about.gitlab.com/pricing/)

- Gold user has 50,000 minutes

If they run continuous fuzzing
- 1 week = 10,080 minutes
- 1 month = 43,800 minutes

That's a big portion of their quota. We need to info user someway about this.

#### Proposed solution 

Figma: https://www.figma.com/file/iKVb1JXx9fKXdZLbc26l5y/Continous-Fuzzing?node-id=407%3A0

- If we can detect the user is using shared running we show the message:
   - Continuous fuzz test will use the pipeline minutes, your maximum pipeline minutes is 50,000 minutes
- If we can not detect the user is using shared running we show the message:
   - For users who use shared runner, continuous fuzz test will use the pipeline minutes

epic.title: Support Continuous Fuzzing for Coverage Guided Fuzzing

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `recursive_approach_for_all_projects`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## What

Remove the `:recursive_approach_for_all_projects` feature flag when there are no issues with the recursive approach for finding all projects for a namespace.

This feature was introduced with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44740.

## Owners

- Team: ~"section::fulfillment"  
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#s_fulfillment`
- Best individual to reach out to: `@cwiesner`, `@tyleramos`, `@ahegyi` (part of a different team though)

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?
We expect an improvement of the query to get all projects for a specific namespace.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?
We might not have an improvement of the query or get wrong results back.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->

## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- `gitlab-org/gitlab` project
- `gitlab-org`/`gitlab-com` groups
- ...

### Availability & Testing

All tests (including end-to-end) must pass before and after this change is made.

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

## Roll Out Steps

- [x] Enable on staging (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true --staging`)
- [x] Test on staging
- ~~[ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated~~ not needed
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for the `gitlab-org/gitlab` project and verify behaviour (`/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab recursive_approach_for_all_projects true`)
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for the groups `gitlab-org` and `gitlab-com and verify behaviour (`/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org recursive_approach_for_all_projects true` and `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-com recursive_approach_for_all_projects true`)
- [x] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with `#production` and `#g_delivery` on slack.
- [x] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for 25% of actors for a day and verify behaviour (`/chatops run feature set recursive_approach_for_all_projects 25 --actors`)
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for 50% of actors for two days and verify behaviour (`/chatops run feature set recursive_approach_for_all_projects 50 --actors`)

title: Align codebase of all 3 gemnasium analyzers
description:
## Summary There are important discrepancies in the codebase of the 3 Gemnasium analyzer projects. These discrepancies need to be removed so that these 3 projects can be eventually share the same codebase, and be merged into a single one. ## Further details - `gemnasium-maven` and `gemnasium-python` depends on [common/command](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/blob/v2.10.2/command), but `gemnasium` doesn't. - `gemnasium` uses [`Scanner.ScanDir`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.21.0/scanner/scanner.go#L104) but `gemnasium-python` uses [`ScanReader`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.21.0/scanner/scanner.go#L152) and `gemnasium-maven` uses [`ScanFile`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.21.0/scanner/scanner.go#L140). - As a consequence, `gemnasium` is the only project that uses [scanner/finder](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.21.0/scanner/finder/finder.go) package, and other projects rely on custom detection logic. - `gemnasium-maven` and `gemnasium-python` both run CLI commands to generate file that can be parsed, whereas `gemnasium` directly parses supported files. - `gemnasium-maven` and `gemnasium-python` look for supported files in a specific order, whereas `gemnasium` doesn't. In the case of `gemnasium-python`, default pip files win over setuptools files, and `PIP_REQUIREMENTS_FILE` wins over everything else. - `gemnasium` scans all the supported files whereas `gemnasium-maven` and `gemnasium-python` stops after the first match. `gemnasium-maven` could technically process multiple files but this would be a behavior change. `gemnasium-python` couldn't because of other limitations - scanned project would leak its dependencies to the next ones. Links - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.21.0/main.go - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/-/blob/v2.15.0/analyze.go - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/blob/v2.18.4/analyze.go ## Proposal - add structs that represent the package managers as well as the files they handle - implement a generic detection logic that leverages these structs and return supported projects; it can be configured to maintain the behavior of `gemnasium-maven` and `gemnasium-python` - introduce "builders" as an abstraction for commands executed to export the dependencies to a file Gemnasium can parse (execution of the Gemnasium Maven plugin, pipenv graph, etc.) - align all CLIs so that they use the same detection logic, build the projects that need to be built (where applicable), and scan them

See initial proposal Share as much code as possible, and let `gemnasium-python` and `gemnasium-maven` implement specific plugins: - `builder` plugins, to build the project and generate files that can be parsed - `parser` plugins, to parse the lock file or dependency graph, and extract a list of packages - `vrange ` plugins, to check if a version is included in a range Each plugin system is implemented in the main `gemnasium` project, and this is where the plugin registry lives. Each plugin lives with the project where its used: - new `builder` plugins are introduced in `gemnasium-maven` and `gemnasium-python` - some existing `vrange` plugins are moved - some existing `scanner/parser` plugins are moved For instance, `vrange/python` moves to `gemnasium-python`, and `scanner/parser/mvnplugin` moves to `gemnasium-maven`. The `gemnasium` project still builds the `gemnasium` Docker image, but it uses the same API as `gemnasium-python` and `gemnasium-maven`, for consistency. In the long term, shared code could be extracted into a separate repository. The `scanner` package becomes generic, and only has two exported methods: - to walk a directory, and build a list of files to be processed - to process that list of files, using compatible builders and parsers The walk function walks the given directory, and finds no more than one file per package type per directory. It queries the registered builders and parsers to figure out what files are supported. Parsers are queried first, so that ready-to-parse lock files win over dependency files (which require some kind of build). The walk function is configurable, and it can optionally stop right after the first match. This way `gemnasium-maven` and `gemnasium-python` can behave like they currently do. The process function replaces `ScanDir`, `ScanFile`, and `ScanReader`, which are no longer needed. Ideally, the `main.go` of a Gemnasium project is simple as: 1. importing builder, parser, and vrange plugins as anonymous 1. creating a `NewApp` using the `gemnasium/cli` package, and running this app

## Implementation plan - introduce "builders" as an abstraction layers for the CLI tools executed to get a parseable dependency list - [x] refactor `gemnasium-maven` using builders https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/merge_requests/78 - [x] refactor `gemnasium-python` using builders https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/-/merge_requests/69 - [x] align `gemnasium` with this, and try it out using a `bundle install` or equivalent - align "finders" so that they all support multiple projects, and so that parseable files win over files that require the execution of a "builder" - [x] implement generic project finder in `gemnasium` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/merge_requests/134 - [x] use generic finder in `gemnasium-maven` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/merge_requests/87 - [x] use generic finder in `gemnasium-python` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/-/merge_requests/76 ## Improvements - codebase is ready to be merged - codebase is more consistent, making contribution easier ## Risks None identified ## Involved components * [gemnasium](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium) * [gemnasium-python](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python) * [gemnasium-maven](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven) ## Optional: Intended side effects - implementing `poetry.lock` support becomes trivial https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/7006 - implementing `Pipfile.lock` support becomes trivial https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/11756 - it becomes easy to make `yarn.lock` win over `package-lock.json` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/198032#note_381075492 - multi-repo support for Java can easily be implemented https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/250650 ## Optional: Missing test coverage None

title: Create test mapping dynamically
description:
Generate test mapping for `test_file_finder` dynamically, part of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/222369.

After spiking a few approaches listed below, the chosen approach is to use crystalball with coverage. This is implemented in !44968 

There are a few options to do this:
1. [`rotoscope`](https://github.com/Shopify/rotoscope) - spike !44886
1. [`TracePoint`](https://ruby-doc.org/core-2.7.0/TracePoint.html) - `rotoscope` uses tracepoint C API internally.
1. [`Coverage`](https://ruby-doc.org/stdlib-2.5.3/libdoc/coverage/rdoc/Coverage.html) - `crystalball` has a Coverage strategy
1. [`crystalball`](https://github.com/toptal/crystalball/) - spike: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/44968

The mapping should list all the test files for each source file in the codebase, to be used with `test_file_finder` gem:

```rb
{
  "app/models/project.rb": ["spec/models/project_spec.rb", ...],
  "app/models/project_feature.rb": ["spec/models/project_spec.rb", ...]
}
```

title: Un-verified email in bio field can look like it is a verified email
description:
**[HackerOne report #996526](https://hackerone.com/reports/996526)** by `xenx` on 2020-10-02, assigned to @ngeorge1:

[Report](#report) | [Attachments](#attachments) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

#####  Summary  

In gitlab , an unverified email id of an account can't be displayed publicly through `Public email`  option it just gives an error like `public email is not an email you own` which is definitely understandable (since a unverified user can get into a private project by impersonating)

![1.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/ef3a7993-c653-4f8b-9db6-70a5967f2e43/1.png)

Case1: For a verified user, the public profile look like this when `public email is enabled` 
 
![2.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/dde44e20-38da-4ec5-9bd2-c5e76cb09673/2.png)

Case2: But the `Public email` option  for a unverified email can be bypassed to show the email publicly using the `bio`. Updating the bio with the unverified email look like this  

![3.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/ec4dd92e-2177-405e-864d-9750deb8dd0b/3.png)

So by using this an attacker can bypass the `public profile option` for a unverified email id(See both case1 and case2 is same) and get into a private project by impersonating through invitation or by requesting access.  

![4.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/648ea61e-b5be-43b6-83c9-26ef0020b487/4.png).


#####  Steps to reproduce

1) Create an account but don't verify it.  
2)Go to https://gitlab.com/profile and try to make the email display as public  
3) You will see ```public email is not an email you own```  
4) Now the update the bio with the email . You will see the profile looks just same to same like a verified email with ```mailto:```.


#####  What is the current *bug* behavior?

Actually when bio is updated ```mailto:``` is added to email link ,hence it acts just like a publicly displayed verified email

#####  What is the expected *correct* behavior?

In bio , ```mailto:``` should not included. Also it would be better if unverified email can't be searchable through project member invitation.

#####  PS

I added the account with ==[@]gitlab.com==  just to show how a malicious user can use ```[@]domain.com``` to impersonate to get into a target private project.

####  Impact

A malicious user can bypass the inability to display the unverified email publicly through `public email option` and improve the odds of a social engineering attack/infiltration being successful.

## Attachments

**Warning:** Attachments received through HackerOne, please exercise caution!

* [1.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/ef3a7993-c653-4f8b-9db6-70a5967f2e43/1.png)
* [2.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/dde44e20-38da-4ec5-9bd2-c5e76cb09673/2.png)
* [3.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/ec4dd92e-2177-405e-864d-9750deb8dd0b/3.png)
* [4.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/648ea61e-b5be-43b6-83c9-26ef0020b487/4.png)

### Problem to solve

Currently the "bio" field allows users to enter emails in multiple ways that look like "verified" emails when displayed.

### Proposals considered

- [Prohibit email addresses in the bio field](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/263411#note_652346121).  Problematic because a migration is required and it will partially delete user input data, neither of which we want to do.  Would only impact approximately 0.05% of SaaS Users, based on a sample of 100K users.
- [Add a "Bio" prefix when displaying](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/263411#note_655484249).  [Problematic](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/68628#note_660870952) because the user can enter a line break then "Verified email: [EMAIL]".
- [Display raw `bio_html`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/68628#note_660870952) (using `html_escape`). Problematic because this "breaks" the display of any bios that include HTML or Markdown.

### Proposal

TBD

### Related links

- Markdown parsing for `bio` was introduced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35604
